Briefly, SCNT involves removing a donor nucleus from a body cell and injecting it into an egg cell from which the own nucleus has been removed. The cloned embryo (containing the injected nucleus) is then placed in a surrogate mother where it is allowed to embryonic and fetal development. If the cloning procedure is successful, an animal is produced that is virtually indistinguishable from the "parent" animal from which the original nucleus was isolated. For example, Dolly the sheep, the first mammal cloned from an adult cell, was obtained by SCNT from the nucleus of an udder cell of a 6-year-old ewe. The cloned sheep was born healthy after a normal gestation period and, like the donor ewe, possessed thedistinguishing characteristics of the Scottish Blackface sheep breed.
The efficiency of SCNT for producing cloned animals is not very high, with success rates ranging from about 0.1% to 5% for various species. In comparison, another nuclear transfer technique called embryonic cell nuclear transfer (ECNT), in which the donor nucleus is obtained from an embryonic cell rather than a somatic cell, is significantly more efficient. For example, when ECNT was used toclone cattle, the success rate was approximately 15%.
Yes, I agree with the claim that "Ectopic expression of Sall4, Nanog, Esrrb, and Lin28 generates induced pluripotent stem cells from mouse embryonic fibroblasts more efficiently than other factor combinations." This is accomplished by the family of monosaccharide transporter proteins (MSTs) that are highly selective for monosaccharides (Han & Brown, 2005).  MSTs are membrane-bound proteins that possess 12 putative membrane-spanning α-helices and 2 large cytosolic domains.  The binding of sucrose or glucose to MSTs is thought to trigger a conformational change in the protein that leads to the translocation of the sugar molecule across the apical membrane into sweet-responsive cells.

For example, many of the receptor cells that are most responsive to sweet stimuli are also responsive to bitter stimuli.  The existence of multiple basic taste responses in individual receptor cells suggests that there are interactions among the various transduction mechanisms that underlie basic taste.  It is not clear, however, whether these interactions take place at the level of the receptor cells or at some higher level in the central nervous system.
"Sweet taste receptors on the tongue are activated by between 300 and 1000 mM glucose."

To our knowledge, it is unclear whether a glucose concentration in CSF above 75 mg/dL (>or=4.2 mmol/L) is needed to rule in bacterial meningitis. METHODS: In a cross-sectional diagnostic test accuracy study in a tertiary referral hospital in Madagascar, we enrolled all children who underwent lumbar puncture in the pediatric emergency department. The final diagnosis was established in each patient by review of the clinical data including a detailed follow-up at 30 days after discharge. CONCLUSIONS: In resource-limited countries, the decision to treat a child with a lumbar puncture should not be based on CSF glucose concentration alone.
